newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turk parliament approves secularist education bill.
newsitem.headline: Turk parliament approves secularist education bill.

text.p: Turkey's parliament on Saturday approved a key education reform bill after a marathon debate that revived tensions between the country's Islamists and secularist establishment.

"Votes in favour 277, votes against 242. Thus the bill has become law. Congratulations," Deputy Speaker Uluc Gurkan told the assembly after a vote at the end of a three-day debate culminating in an overnight session.
The secularist schooling reforms are at the heart of a military-led campaign against religious activism in Turkey and have fuelled street protests by Islamists.

After Friday prayers police fired water cannon and used batons to break up a crowd of about 2,000 Islamists in Istanbul. More than 100 people were arrested across the country during demonstrations which had been outlawed by authorities.
In the wake of the protests, one Welfare deputy said the real test of public support for the new law would be general elections expected to take place next year.
"You can ban people from the streets but you cannot ban them from the ballot box," Welfare deputy Ahmet Demircan told tired deputies, sustained through a night of speeches by soup and tea.
Islamists believe the future of religious schools, known as Imam Hatips, will be threatened by the law drafted by the seven-week old secularist coalition under Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz.
Under the law, compulsory state schooling is extended to eight years from five, effectively bringing an end to the primary section of Imam Hatips.

The armed forces, self-appointed guardians of the state's secularism, demanded introduction of the law in February as part of an offensive against the Islamist-led government under Welfare leader Necmettin Erbakan.
